awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's magnetotail is the elongated portion of Earth's magnetic field formed on the night (or anti-sunward) side of the magnetosphere. This region is characterized by energy release that accompanies the reconfiguration (aka 'reconnection') of oppositely directed magnetic field lines. In the process, magnetic field energy is converted to plasma kinetic and thermal energy. The researchers will perform computer simulations to investigate the roles played by several types of magneto-hydrodynamical instabilities. This work will contribute to fundamental knowledge of plasma discontinuities and magnetic reconnection. These processes are pertinent not only to Earth,  but also to solar, planetary and stellar magnetospheres, as well as fusion devices and laboratory reconnection experiments. Knowledge derived from the work will advance understanding and modeling of space weather. Educational benefits will be provided in the form of hands-on research training for student summer interns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to resolve the mechanisms of spontaneous magnetotail reconnection and concurrent non-reconnection processes, such as the plasma buoyancy motions. Magnetic reconnection occurs when the initial strongly stretched magnetic field changes its topology and releases energy to accelerate and heat plasma particles. We aimed to answer the following science questions: 1) Under what conditions does reconnection dominate over non-reconnection instabilities? 2) What makes the reconnection instability possible relatively far from Earth where conventional magnetotail current models are too thick to provide dissipation necessary for the spontaneous topology change? 3) What are the distinctive features of collisionless dissipation and Hall effects in reconnecting magnetotail and what are their implications for magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) treatment of the tail reconnection?

 

A distinctive feature of the methodology was combining first-principles simulations, MHD and PIC (particle-in-cell kinetic simulations), with empirical reconstructions of the tail magnetic field using data mining methods. The latter use the recurring nature of geomagnetically active events, storms and substorms to sort historical records of spaceborne magnetometers over several decades and from multiple missions, to select a small subset of the historical database describing only events most similar to the event of interest. Recently it has been shown that such a data mining approach allows one to reconstruct the details of the structure and evolution of the magnetotail current sheet before and after reconnection. These reconstructions can then be used to both guide MHD and PIC simulations of the onset plasma instabilities and compare the simulation results with the observed picture of the tail evolution during magnetospheric substorms.

 

The study yielded a number of interesting results, the most striking of which is the consistent description of steady and unsteady regimes of magnetic reconnection: Both data mining reconstructions and PIC simulations of magnetotail show two different regimes of reconnection processes in the magnetotail in different regions (Image 1). In the mid tail the reconnection process is steady and its rate is consistent with theoretical estimates. Closer to Earth, reconnection is unsteady, which can be seen from drastic changes of the magnetic field geometry (magnetic field line dipolarization). It is also shown that reconnection is provided by ion and then electron demagnetization and it is preceded by the formation of electron and ion watersheds, patterns of diverging electron and ion plasma flows, the effect found in observations of the Magnetospheric MultiScale (MMS) mission. In 3D, the reconnection motions, including dipolarization fronts, are perturbed by buoyancy and flapping motions of the tail current sheets. The latter however disturb but don’t destroy the reconnection structure and evolution. Another impressive outcome of this project is the finding that most of all reconnection regions, which were detected by MMS in 2017-2020, can be reconstructed by the data mining method. This finding suggests that magnetic reconnection indeed controls the global structure and evolution of the substorm magnetosphere.
